department.en: Graduate School, Division of Natural Science
Graduate School, Division of Natural Science

description.en: Soil is presented as evidence as a mixture of both natural and artificial materials. 'Unique' particles found in soil may provide useful information to indicate the origin of the soil and, when found in soil evidence, may provide rapid discrimination between samples. Evidence in poor condition may also be examined for these diagnostic particles. This paper describes some case examples and research, involving geological particles, plant fragments and algae, in which microscopy played an important role. © The Geological Society of London, 2004.

publication_name.ja: Forensic Geoscience: Principles, Techniques and Applications. Geological Society Special Publications

paper_title.en: Screening of soil evidence by a combination of simple techniques: validity of particle size distribution

description.en: The validity of the determination of particle size distribution for forensic soil identification was studied using 73 soil samples collected from a 20 km x 15 km area. Soil particles were first divided into two fractions by wet sieving with a sieve with a 0.05 mm aperture size. Dry sieving was used to analyze the coarse particle fraction and a particle size analyzer was used for the fine particle fraction. The number of particle size classes measured by sieving could be reduced to three, <0.05, 0.05-0.2, and 0.2-2 mm, which enabled 87.9% of the soil samples to be discriminated. Measurements made with the particle size analyzer on the fine particle fraction increased the discriminating power to 95.9%. The use of particle size analysis by sieving in combination with color examination allowed us to discriminate 99.5% of the soil samples, even when particle size analysis of the fine particle fraction was not carried out. (C) 2001 Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Validity of color examination for forensic soil identification

description.en: The validity of a multiple measurement procedure for forensic soil identification was studied using 73 soil samples from an area where volcanic ash soils, alluvial soils and residual soils dominate. Soil color was measured by comparison to Munsell color charts after each of several treatments: (1) air-drying, (2) moistening, (3) organic matter decomposition, (4) iron oxide removal, and (5) ashing. In addition, the colors of the clay fractions were observed after organic matter decomposition and after iron oxide removal. Although only about 70% of soils could be differentiated by comparing the colors of air-dried samples, combining color measurements on soils after air-drying and moistening, and on the clay fraction after organic matter decomposition and iron oxide removal enabled us to differentiate 97% of soil samples. Adding color measurements of ashed soil to the above procedure did not provide any further improvement in the discriminatory power of the multiple color measurement.

research_project_title.en: Presumption of soil collecting point using geoscientific, chemical and biological method.

offer_organization.en: Japan Society for the Promotion of Science

institution_name.en: National Research Institute of Police Science

description.ja:
本年度は、昨年度の結果を踏まえ、フッ化水素酸等の危険度の高い試薬を用いず、安全に実験が可能な土壌有機物の前処理によって得られた資料を用いて土壌有機物の分析を実施した。
有機化学的な分析の結果、今回用いた資料では近隣地域の資料（多くは畑地土壌）であったことから、大きな相違は認められず、地域や植生が大きく異なる資料を用いて分析を実施する必要があるものと考えられた。
現在得られている差異があまり認められない解析データでも統計学的解析によって差が見出せるようになるかについて、生データ（アナログデータ）のデジタル化を行った上で、様々な数学的前処理（クロマトグラムの微分処理や平滑化、基準化等）を試行錯誤し、より客観的な異同識別の評価ができるよう、引き続き検討を行う。
植物DNAの分析については、土壌からのDNA抽出法を確立し、NGS解析に用いることが可能なDNA抽出物を得ることができるようになった。
今後、当研究室で既に実用化されているNGS解析を実施し、植物DNAが植生（作物）を反映しているのかについて、その関係性を明らかにする。

research_project_title.ja: 微細証拠資料の法科学的検査法

research_project_title.en: Examination of trace evidence for forensic science
